channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: A Refuge for Afghan Music Is at Risk of Falling Silent
item.description: Peshawar is a haven for Afghan artists who fled from the Taliban, which had banned music. A new policy of deportations by Pakistan threatens this community of exiles.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Asim Hafeez
item.category: Destruction of Cultural Antiquities and Heritage
item.media:credit: Asim Hafeez for The New York Times

item.title: The $2 Rental Batteries Helping to Power South Africa
item.description: The batteries offer an affordable system for those who lack reliable power and the money to buy their own solar panels.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Joao Silva
item.media:description: Anselmo Mugabe, in stripy shirt, who runs a hair Salon in Thembisa, a township north east of Johannesburg, uses the BPowerD batteries in order to run his business.

item.title: Iran Protests Quelled Since Deadly Crackdown, Residents Say
item.description: “There is massive disappointment and disillusionment,” one Tehran resident said. A human rights group acknowledged that demonstrations had been subdued since Sunday, with thousands of people detained.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir, Kiana Hayeri, Sanam Mahoozi and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A burned bus at Sadeghieh Square in Tehran on Thursday, after the protests were largely subdued.

item.title: Trump Chooses Venezuela’s Oil Over Democracy
item.description: Two conversations this week confirmed that President Trump backs the remnants of Nicolás Maduro’s regime over the Venezuelan opposition seeking to hold elections.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:description: Delcy Rodríguez, the interim president of Venezuela, moments before her swearing-in in Caracas, the country’s capital, in January.

item.title: Antiwar Russians in Europe Learn That They Must Watch Their Words
item.description: A backlash over a rant against Ukrainian officials has raised questions about Eastern Europe’s welcome of Russian dissidents.
item.dc:creator: Nataliya Vasilyeva and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: Officials in Lithuania, where Leonid Volkov, a Russian dissident, has lived for years, have called for his expulsion after comments criticizing Ukrainian officials were leaked.

item.title: Iran Has Had Protests Before. Will This Time Be Different?
item.description: Understanding the factors that can topple regimes.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Protesters in Tehran, Iran, last week.

item.title: Canada Strikes Tariffs Deal With China, as Carney Looks to Diversify From U.S.
item.description: China will in turn cut its own tariffs on Canadian canola products, Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada said in Beijing on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada meeting on Friday with Xi Jinping, China’s leader, at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing.

item.title: How Italy Is Struggling to Finish an Ice Rink Before the Olympics
item.description: With less than a month until the Winter Games in northern Italy, builders have yet to complete a major arena.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich, Josephine de La Bruyère and Alessandro Grassani
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times

item.title: After Trump Call, Colombia’s Petro Turns Up Heat on Far-Left Armed Group
item.description: President Gustavo Petro of Colombia is taking a harder line against the National Liberation Army, or ELN, a leftist group experts call a powerful drug trafficker in Colombia and Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal, Genevieve Glatsky and Max Bearak
item.media:description: National Liberation Army, or ELN, rebels in the Catatumbo region of Colombia last year.

item.title: Right-Wing Leaders of Italy and Japan Become Fast Friends
item.description: At a meeting in Tokyo, Prime Ministers Giorgia Meloni of Italy and Sanae Takaichi of Japan bonded over being conservative women at the pinnacle of power.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández and Motoko Rich
item.media:description: Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni of Italy, left, and Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi of Japan during a news conference in Tokyo on Friday.

item.title: Ex-South Korean Leader Gets Prison Term in First Ruling Over Martial Law
item.description: A court handed down five years in prison to former President Yoon Suk Yeol, who is facing multiple trials stemming from his short-lived imposition of martial law.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Jun Michael Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: A police convoy leaving the residence of former President Yoon Suk Yeol after detaining him in January 2025.

item.title: Greek Court Acquits Rescue Workers Accused of Smuggling Migrants
item.description: The 24 former volunteers, including the refugee turned campaigner Sara Mardini, were prosecuted after helping migrants during the European refugee crisis nearly a decade ago.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Some of the aid workers and their lawyers outside the courthouse on Thursday in Lesbos, Greece, after they were acquitted of all charges.

item.title: Death Toll Rises to 28 After Landfill Collapse in the Philippines
item.description: Rescuers in Cebu City have recovered 28 bodies from a garbage mound that collapsed last week. The search continues for eight missing people.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado
item.media:description: Search and recovery operations at a collapsed waste management facility in Binaliw, Cebu City, Philippines, on Sunday.

item.title: ‘Squished Between Chairs’ on a Train: How Some Passengers Survived a Crane Collapse
item.description: Some travelers were able to squeeze out of mangled cars and others were rescued by residents, after the accident in northeastern Thailand. Dozens did not survive.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono and Lauren DeCicca
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times

item.title: Uganda’s Election Goes Ahead, Despite Major Delays at the Polls
item.description: Technical failures at polling places caused major disruptions, and the opposition has warned of protests and government vote rigging.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Musinguzi Blanshe
item.media:description: Voters lining up at a polling station in Kampala, Uganda, on Thursday.

item.title: Gabriel Barkay, 81, Dies; His Discoveries Revised Biblical History
item.description: One of Israel’s leading archaeologists, he found evidence that the writing of the Old Testament likely began much earlier than historians had thought.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Gabriel Barkay in 2016, displaying a restored ancient tile excavated from the holy site in Jerusalem known to Jews as the Temple Mount. He earned a reputation as the “dean” of biblical archaeologists.

item.title: Trump Has Machado’s Nobel Prize, but Neither Got What They Really Wanted
item.description: President Trump has María Corina Machado’s medal, but he is not recognized as the prize laureate. Ms. Machado did not win Mr. Trump’s endorsement to become Venezuela’s president.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: María Corina Machado’s decision to present her Nobel Peace Prize medal to President Trump has been met with mixed reviews in the United States and abroad.

item.title: Thousands Evicted From Makoko, the ‘Venice of Nigeria’
item.description: Community leaders in Lagos say evictions in the name of development have left many residents of this fishing village homeless.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey and Taiwo Aina
item.media:credit: Taiwo Aina for The New York Times
item.media:description: At the Makoko community, in Lagos, this week.

item.title: Syria’s President Affirms Kurds’ Rights, in Overture to the Minority
item.description: President Ahmed al-Sharaa’s announcement comes after days of deadly clashes between government and Kurdish forces that have underscored the difficulty he faces in uniting the country.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: People crossing a bridge as they flee from a Kurdish-controlled area, in Rasm al-Harmal, east of Aleppo, on Friday.

item.title: Bobi Wine, Ugandan Opposition Leader, Was Abducted, His Party Says
item.description: Mr. Wine’s party said on X that “an army helicopter” had landed in his compound and “forcibly” taken him away ahead of election results in Uganda, during a nationwide internet blackout.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Supporters of the opposition leader Bobi Wine in Kampala, Uganda, on Monday.

item.title: Russian Strikes Force Kyiv Schools to Close Amid Rolling Blackouts
item.description: Russia has targeted Ukraine’s energy infrastructure in past winters, but this year intensified its attacks as temperatures in Ukraine plunged well below freezing.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Oksana Parafeniuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: A residential area during a power blackout this month in Kyiv.

item.title: How Greenland Is Reacting to Trump’s Threats
item.description: Our reporter Jeffrey Gettleman is on the ground in Greenland, seeing how people have reacted to Trump’s desire to take it over. He and our senior writer Katrin Bennhold discuss what Greenland means to the United States, Denmark and Greenlanders.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold, Jeffrey Gettleman, Leila Medina and James Surdam

item.title: C.I.A. Director Meets With Venezuela’s Interim President in Caracas
item.description: The high-profile visit, which could be seen as snubbing the opposition, comes nearly two weeks after the U.S. military seized President Nicolás Maduro in a raid.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: John Ratcliffe, the C.I.A. director, at the U.S. Capitol last week. On Thursday, he met with Delcy Rodríguez, the interim president of Venezuela, and delivered a message of cooperation.

item.title: Many Fiery Remarks, Little Clarity on What’s Next at Security Council Meeting on Iran
item.description: Iran’s representative denied the country had killed protesters, as the U.S. ambassador said President Trump had made clear “all options are on the table” to stop the killing.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ahmad Batebi, right, a human-rights activist, delivered remarks at the United Nations Security Council meeting on Iran on Thursday.

item.title: Venezuela’s Interim Leader Delivers State of the Union Address
item.description: In her State of the Union address, Delcy Rodríguez echoed her predecessors’ fiery rhetoric but tried to hew to President Trump’s agenda.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Patricia Sulbarán
item.media:description: Venezuela’s interim president, Delcy Rodríguez, delivering a speech at the National Assembly in Caracas on Thursday.

item.title: The Nobel Peace Prize Medal Has Been Sold Before for Millions
item.description: The Nobel Committee has said the prize cannot be transferred, but it has been sold in a few auctions over the award’s history.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:description: Since the 1980s, the Nobel medal has been made with recycled gold.

item.title: How Activists in Iran Are Using Starlink to Stay Online
item.description: Activists spent years preparing for a communications blackout in Iran, smuggling in Starlink satellite internet systems and making digital shutdowns harder for the authorities to enforce.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur and Sheera Frenkel
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Middle East Images/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Starlink receiver atop a house in Kurdistan, Iran, in 2023. About 50,000 Starlink terminals are now in the country, according to digital activists.

item.title: A Healthy Brain
item.description: Even when so much is happening in the world, it’s important to take care of your brain health. Our Well desk shares tips.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

item.title: Italian Court Closes Fraud Case Against Influencer Chiara Ferragni
item.description: A judge dropped a case against Chiara Ferragni tied to her promotion of a Christmas pandoro marketed as supporting cancer treatment.
item.dc:creator: Josephine de La Bruyère and Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Chiara Ferragni arriving at the Milan Courthouse on Wednesday. A judge dismissed the fraud case against the influencer, but prosecutors could still consider an appeal.

item.title: Israel and Arab Nations Ask Trump to Refrain From Attacking Iran
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel asked the president to postpone any planned attack. Israeli and Arab officials fear Iran could retaliate by striking their countries.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Tyler Pager and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel with President Trump last month in Florida. The Israeli leader spoke to Mr. Trump on Wednesday, the same day that the president claimed Iran had stopped killing protesters.

item.title: Cuba Receives Remains of 32 Citizens Killed in U.S. Strikes in Venezuela
item.description: The Cubans had served as part of the security detail of Nicolás Maduro, Venezuela’s ousted president.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.media:description: A motorcade transporting the Cuban‑flag‑draped urns of citizens killed in the U.S. strike in Venezuela earlier this month.

item.title: Why Israel Is Wary of Intervening in Iran
item.description: Israel is unlikely to do much to try to precipitate a regime change in Iran, seeing the government as far from the brink of collapse and the current protests as insufficient to push it to that point.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger
item.media:description: A photograph posted on social media showing a protest in Tehran last week.

item.title: U.S. Cuts Health Aid and Ties It to Funding Pledges by African Governments
item.description: The Trump administration has signed $11 billion in agreements with African nations, in deals tied to foreign policy goals.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:credit: Gulshan Khan for The New York Times
item.media:description: A health clinic in Mhlosheni, Eswatini, in May. Health funding from the U.S. to Eswatini — where a quarter of adults live with H.I.V. — would drop by 34 percent under the new agreement between the two countries.

item.title: UK Conservatives Fire Senior Lawmaker Over ‘Plot’ to Defect
item.description: The leader of Britain’s Conservatives, Kemi Badenoch, expelled Robert Jenrick for “plotting in secret” to defect from and damage the party. He later confirmed he was joining Reform U.K.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Lizzie Dearden
item.media:description: Robert Jenrick, who ran to lead the Conservative Party last year in Britain, was dismissed by the party’s leader on Thursday.

item.title: Elon Musk’s X Restricts Ability to Create Explicit Images With Grok
item.description: Bowing to pressure, the company said it would restrict X users from generating explicit images of real people in jurisdictions where such content is illegal.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: Andria Lo for The New York Times
item.media:description: The prompt page for Grok, the artificial intelligence chatbot made by Elon Musk’s xAI.

item.title: After an Inconclusive Meeting With Trump Administration Officials Over Greenland’s Future, What’s Next?
item.description: A high-powered meeting in Washington on Wednesday ended in an impasse, leaving Greenlanders fearful of what comes next.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Maya Tekeli
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Greenland’s foreign minister, Vivian Motzfeldt, left, and Denmark’s foreign minister, Lars Lokke Rasmussen, center left, meeting with senators in Washington on Wednesday.

item.title: Iran Backpedals on Executions Threat but Casts Protesters as ‘Terrorists’
item.description: Iran’s judiciary said there was no death penalty issued for Erfan Soltani, whose case drew international outcry. Analysts say the government is using fear and intimidation to keep people off the streets.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Sanam Mahoozi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Nearly 5 Million Accounts Removed Under Australia’s New Social Media Ban
item.description: Governments around the world are watching the rollout of the landmark law, which made it illegal for those under 16 to have accounts.
item.dc:creator: Laura Chung and Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: The law required 10 social media platforms, including Instagram, Facebook, Snapchat and Reddit, to prevent users under 16 from accessing their services.

item.title: Russia Knocks Out the Heat in Ukraine
item.description: The Kremlin has tried for years to freeze Ukraine into submission. This winter, its attacks have been the most devastating ever.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Oksana Parafeniuk and Lynsey Addario
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency services have set up tents that offer electricity and heat as Russian strikes have caused prolonged power outages during an extreme cold snap in Kyiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Machado Presents Trump With Nobel Peace Prize
item.description: The Venezuelan opposition leader’s efforts to share her award with the U.S. president have shaken some Norwegians’ faith in their signature soft-power tool.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak and Henrik Pryser Libell
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Venezuelan opposition politician María Corina Machado outside the U.S. Capitol in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: The U.S. Is Pressing Mexico to Allow U.S. Forces to Fight Cartels
item.description: The United States is escalating pressure on the Mexican government to permit the U.S. military to target fentanyl labs, according to American officials.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib, Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: White powder, purportedly finished fentanyl, sitting on a table in a makeshift lab operated by the Sinaloa cartel.

item.title: Venezuela Strongman and Maduro Ally, Diosdado Cabello, Faces an Uneasy Transition
item.description: Diosdado Cabello, Venezuela’s interior minister, is accused by U.S. prosecutors of drug trafficking and is linked to repression at home, yet remains a powerful figure.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Diosdado Cabello, Venezuela’s interior minister, welcoming a flight bringing Venezuelan migrants from Mexico last year.

item.title: Thailand Has 2nd Deadly Accident Involving a Crane in 2 Days
item.description: The crane’s collapse, which killed at least two people outside Bangkok, came a day after another crane fell on a train in the northeast, leaving at least 32 people dead.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Kittiphum Sringammuang
item.media:description: The site where a construction crane collapsed onto a highway in Samut Sakhon Province, Thailand, on Thursday.

item.title: James Luckey-Lange Among Americans Freed in Venezuela
item.description: James Luckey-Lange, 28, was released this week with several other U.S. citizens from the country’s notorious prison system after going missing in December, his family said.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Edward Wong

item.title: British Columbia Ends Program That Aimed to Curb Arrests of Drug Users
item.description: The three-year pilot program did not deliver the results hoped for, the health minister said. It had allowed drug users to avoid criminal charges for possessing small amounts of illegal substances.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Chad Hipolito/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Josie Osborne, the minister of health in British Columbia, announced on Wednesday that a drug decriminalization program would end on Jan. 31.

item.title: Trump’s Gulf Allies Do Not Want Him to Bomb Iran
item.description: While several of the Gulf Arab countries harbor little love for Iran, they worry that the consequences of rising tensions could blow back on them.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A patriotic banner in Tehran on Wednesday.

item.title: Minneapolis ‘Feels Like a Military Occupation’
item.description: President Trump has sent ICE agents into cities across America. We take a look at the fallout and what may come next.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: Minneapolis on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Races to Sell Venezuelan Oil, Transforming Ties With Former Foe
item.description: U.S. officials brokered the sale of hundreds of millions of dollars worth of Venezuelan oil to stabilize the country’s economy after capturing its president.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: An oil jack in Venezuela’s Orinoco Belt, the country’s main crude producing area.

item.title: U.K. Home Secretary Presses Police Chief to Resign Over Israeli Soccer Fan Ban
item.description: An independent report said Wednesday that the West Midlands Police overstated the threat posed by Maccabi Tel Aviv supporters before a match last year in Birmingham.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden and Tariq Panja
item.media:description: During the Maccabi Tel Aviv versus Aston Villa match in Birmingham, England, in November. The section meant for away fans remained empty.

item.title: What Are Trump’s Options in Iran?
item.description: President Trump has said that “help is on the way” for Iranian protesters. Amid reports that thousands of the protesters have been killed, our national security correspondent David E. Sanger describes what some of Mr. Trump’s options might be.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Coleman Lowndes, Nikolay Nikolov, Edward Vega, June Kim and Whitney Shefte

item.title: Renfrew Christie Dies at 76; Sabotaged Racist Regime’s Nuclear Program
item.description: He played a key role in ending apartheid South Africa’s secret weapons program in the 1980s by helping the African National Congress bomb critical facilities.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: Renfrew Christie in 1988. After Dr. Christie’s death, President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa praised his “relentless and fearless commitment to our freedom.”

item.title: Quebec Premier François Legault Resigns Ahead of Elections
item.description: Premier François Legault became Canada’s most popular provincial leader during the pandemic thanks to his reassuring, avuncular persona. But missteps sank his hopes for a third term.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Jacques Boissinot/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Premier François Legault of Quebec announcing his resignation on Wednesday.

item.title: Toby Kiers, World Champion of Mycorrhizal Fungus
item.description: This year’s recipient of the Tyler Prize for Environmental Achievement talks about “punk science,” microbial economics and thinking like a mycorrhizal fungus.
item.dc:creator: Alan Burdick
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times

item.title: Iran Postpones Execution of Protester as Trump Threatens ‘Strong Action’
item.description: Iran had planned to put a 26-year-old protester to death amid the wave of unrest in the country, but apparently stood down for now.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir, Sanam Mahoozi and Ephrat Livni
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A still from a video posted on social media of cars set on fire during a protest in Tehran last week.

item.title: U.K. Retreats on Plan to Require ‘BritCard’ ID for Workers
item.description: Workers will be able to use a variety of digital IDs to prove their right to work in Britain, the government said Wednesday, diluting a plan it announced last year.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain on Wednesday. He announced plans in September for a new digital ID, but on Wednesday, officials said that other methods could allow a person to work.

item.title: Why Greenland Matters for a Warming World
item.description: The fate of the world’s largest island has outsize importance for billions of people on the planet, because as the climate warms, Greenland is losing ice. That has consequences.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: A frozen sea inlet outside Nuuk, Greenland, last year. In the 12 months ending on Aug. 31, 2025, Greenland lost 105 billion metric tons of ice, scientists say.

item.title: Venezuela Envoy to Visit U.S. for First Official Trip in Years
item.description: Félix Plasencia, an envoy of the interim government, will travel to the United States on the day the opposition leader María Corina Machado is to meet President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Félix Plasencia, then Venezuela’s foreign minister, in Caracas, Venezuela, in 2022.
